title: White House Ballroom Funded by Corporate Donors - $300-400 Million Project
summary: Trump announced White House ballroom expansion, demolishing historic East Wing and replacing it with 89,000 sq ft facility funded entirely by private corporate donors. Cost estimates ballooned from initial $200 million to $300 million and ultimately $400 million. Construction continued during October 2025 federal government shutdown while federal workers went unpaid. Major donors include tech giants (Apple, Amazon, Google, Microsoft, Meta), defense contractors (Lockheed Martin: $10M+), and companies with massive government contracts. White House released donor list in October 2025 but refused to disclose individual donation amounts. Alphabet pledged $22 million of a settlement. Ethics watchdogs warned privately funding the project gives wealthy donors unfair access to the president.
keyFacts: July 2025: White House announced ballroom construction to begin
89,000-square-foot expansion to replace demolished East Wing
East Wing demolished in October 2025 - historic building destroyed
Cost estimate increased from $200 million to $300 million to $400 million
Construction continued during October 2025 federal government shutdown
Entirely funded by private corporate donors, not taxpayer money
October 22, 2025: White House released donor list without individual amounts
By end of October, $350 million had been raised from private donors
37 total donors including tech giants and defense contractors
Major tech donors: Apple, Amazon, Google, Microsoft, Meta, Coinbase, Comcast
Defense contractor Lockheed Martin contributed more than $10 million
Alphabet pledged $22 million of a settlement toward construction
Donations are tax-deductible through nonprofit Trust for the National Mall
Many donor companies have billions in government contracts
Ethics watchdogs: privately funding gives wealthy donors unfair presidential access
Construction proceeded while 800,000 federal workers went unpaid during shutdown
